awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Intrinsic Gas-phase Properties of Peptides: Thermochemistry, Fragmentation Mechanisms, H/D exchange and IRMPD Spectroscopy.
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms program is supporting the collaborative research of Professor John C. Poutsma at the College of William and Mary and Professor Jennifer Poutsma at Old Dominion University.  Professor John Poutsma employs mass spectrometry-based experiments to study the subtle interplay between the structure of peptides and their gas-phase energetic properties. He studies peptides containing non-protein amino acids (NPAA), which are found naturally in plants and fungi, but are not used in natural protein synthesis. Many NPAAs are toxic to humans and other animals in part due to structural similarity to one or more of the twenty common protein amino acids (PAA). NPAAs can compete with PAAs in a variety of biological pathways including being mis-incorporated into proteins and peptides. Studying the behavior of peptides into which NPAAs have been systematically substituted helps to understand the relationship between a peptide?s structure and its behavior in the mass spectrometer. Ultimately this enhanced understanding may lead to improved automated peptide sequencing algorithms for proteomics experiments. Professor Jennifer Poutsma performs density functional theory calculations to predict structure and energetics that support and guide the experimental studies. Both research programs integrate research and educational components through the training of undergraduate researchers.  This research is carried out by undergraduates at William and Mary and Old Dominion University. Performing independent research helps to teach these students not only the joy of discovery but also how to handle and work through the inevitable failures that accompany real-world science.

In this research, intrinsic gas-phase properties of peptides and their fragments are determined using 1) the extended kinetic method, 2) hydrogen deuterium exchange, 3) infrared multiphoton dissociation spectroscopy, 4) peptide fragmentation studies and 5) density functional computations. The ultimate goals of these studies are to establish the relationship between amino acid structure and thermochemical properties, to better understand the effects of intramolecular hydrogen bonding on the gas-phase chemistry of amino acids and peptides, and to explain the mechanisms for ?selective? fragmentations in low-energy tandem mass spectrometry experiments. This detailed knowledge may be integrated into peptide sequencing methods so that they can better account for the presence of unusual amino acids, and for selective fragmentations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit.

The goal of the proposed research was to further our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of and energetic requirements for peptide fragmentation experiments in tandem mass spectrometers (MS). These experiments form the basis of MS-based proteomics experiments aimed at an enhanced knowledge of the behavior of proteins. Though highly automated, these MS-based proteomics experiments rely on empirically-derived "rules" for how peptides fall apart in mass spectrometers. Our goal is to improve our understanding of these "rules" so as to better predict when they will fail.

The "rules" specify that when energy is added to peptides in the mass spectrometer, they fragment to give bn+ and ym+ ions, where n and m are the number of amino acids in the individual fragments. By studying the mechanisms of fragmentation and the instances when the "rules" fail, we have a better chance of predicting the distribution of fragment ions from any given dissociation. Much of the research in this on-going study is centered on determining the mechanisms of peptide fragmentation and obtaining a better understanding of the proline effect, which is an example of when the "rules" fail. In the proline effect, peptides containing a proline residue fragment just before the proline residue and give mainly y+ ions.

Most of our research over the grant period was focused on calculating the proton affinities of the terminal amine or side chain for basic amino acids, the amide oxygen (calculated by Dr. J.C. Poutsma's students) and the amide nitrogen of Pro-XXX and XXX-Pro dipeptides. The XXX-Pro and Pro-XXX dipeptides are used to study the change in protonation site that must occur prior to fragmentation. The preferred protonation site is the terminal amine or the side chain for His, Arg and Lys, but the proton must move to the amide nitrogen for fragmentation to occur. By comparing this series, we can see if the proton affinity or neighboring residues contribute to the proline effect. We have also calculated the terminal amine (or side chain) proton affinities of pipecolic acid (the six-membered ring analog of proline, Pip) and the four-membered ring analog of proline (Aze) dipeptides: Pip-XXX, XXX-Pip, Aze-XXX, XXX-Aze, to gain further insight into the proline effect. While all of these calculations are complete, most of the data hasn't been analyzed yet. However, our calculated proton affinities of the Pro-XXX and XXX-Pro dipeptides are in good agreement with the experimentally determined proton affinities (Dr. J.C. Poutsma, College of William and Mary).

Analysis of the Pro-XXX data shows that no correlation exists between the proton affinities of the N-terminal (excluding His, Arg and Lys), the amide N and the amide O. Interestingly, the N-terminal/side chain proton affinities do correlate with the proton affinity of the XXX amino acid, even though it is the proline that is protonated. Not surprisingly, for all amino acids, the dipeptide has a higher proton affinity than the individual XXX amino acid since the dipeptides are significantly larger than the individual amino acid and size has a large effect on stability in the gas phase.

Another area of research has been examining the factors that effect whether a b2+ ion is made via oxazolone, diketopiperazine or in the case of lys, lactam formation. Calculation of the diketopiperazine and oxazolone pathways for APA and AdiMePA, show that the concerted pathway is preferred over the step-wise pathway. Surprisingly, the APA barriers for diketopiperazine and oxazolone formation were identical, which seems to indicate that the experimental observation of oxazolone formation for APA results from the peptide's preference for the trans conformation. For AdiMePA, the concerted pathway for diketopiperazine formation could not be located. The proton on the second amide always transfered to the terminal amine before ring formation could occur. Thus, it appears AdiMePA fragments via oxazolone despite its initial cis conformation because diketopiperazine formation is not viable. So far, the data suggest many factors may influence whether a peptide fragments via oxazolone or diketopiperazine. Investigation of additional peptides may further elucidate these details.

Broader Impacts

Over the past four years, 13 undergraduate students and 1 master's student have worked on this project at ODU. Two of these students used this research for their senior thesis and one of the students was part of ODU's REU program. Two students are currently in pharmacy school, three are in medical school, one is in a chemistry Ph.D. program, two are working for chemical companies and plan to attend graduate school in the future, and four students are still undergraduates, two of which have plans to attend graduate school. These students have learned that research involves both successes and failures and that a research project is dynamic based on these outcomes. This experience will help them in future endeavors and prepare those who continue doing research to understand the difference between research and a lab class.


Last Modified: 01/11/2023
Modified by: Jennifer L Poutsma
